prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal is to detect CO J=1-0 line in absorption across the Galactic disk at the sound speed resolution (0.3 km/s).
To cover the velocity range of the Galactic plane at the high resolution, we will use 117.188 MHz bandwidth for Baseband-1. We will configure the other three bands at one of the widest bandwidths (1875MHz or 2000MHz) to obtain the total of 6GHz for the continuum.
ALTHOUGH OT DID NOT ALLOW ME TO MAKE THE SETUP, we intend to observe J1851+005 and J1924+156, alternately in a single track without additonal phase calibrator integrations. J1851+005 has the flux of 356 mJy at 100GHz, and J1924+156 has 302 mJy (as of Nov 2013, based on CARMA obs). Each of these two QSOs is self-calibratable. The two are relatively close to each other (17 deg separation in the sky) and easy to observe in a single track.
We aim at the RMS sensitivity of 4mJy in a 0.30km/s channel. For the QSOs with flux of 300mJy, this sensitivity corresponds to the optical depth of 0.05 - 2.93 at 4 sigma. [Note, we need to detect both the decrement from the continuum, f*(1-exp(-tau)), and the absorbed flux, f*exp(-tau), significantly, where f is the flux of the QSO. To detect both at >n*sigma, the equations to be satisfied are f*(1-exp(-tau))>n*sigma and f*exp(-tau)>n*sigma.]

The goal is to simultaneosly detect 13CO and C18O J=1-0 lines in absorption across the Galactic disk at the sound speed resolution (0.3 km/s).
To cover the velocity range of the Galactic plane at the high resolution, we will use 117.188 MHz bandwidth for Baseband-1 and 2. We will configure the other bands at one of the widest bandwidths (1875MHz or 2000MHz) to obtain the total of 6GHz for the continuum.
ALTHOUGH OT DID NOT ALLOW ME TO MAKE THE SETUP, we will observe two QSOs, J1851+005 and J1924+156, alternately in a single track without additonal phase calibrator integrations. J1851+005 has the flux of 356 mJy at 100GHz, and J1924+156 has 302 mJy (as of Nov 2013, based on CARMA obs). Each of these two QSOs is self-calibratable. The two are relatively close to each other (17 deg separation in the sky) and easy to observe in a single track.
We aim at the RMS sensitivity of 4mJy in a 0.30km/s channel. For the QSOs with flux of 300mJy, this sensitivity corresponds to the optical depth of 0.05 - 2.93 at 4 sigma. [Note, we need to detect both the decrement from the continuum, f*(1-exp(-tau)), and the absorbed flux, f*exp(-tau), significantly, where f is the flux of the QSO. To detect both at >n*sigma, the equations to be satisfied are f*(1-exp(-tau))>n*sigma and f*exp(-tau)>n*sigma.]

The goal is to simultaneosly detect CO J=2-1 line in absorption across the Galactic disk at the sound speed resolution (0.3 km/s).
To cover the velocity range of the Galactic plane at the high resolution, we will use 234.375 MHz bandwidth for Baseband-1. We will configure the other three bands at one of the widest bandwidths (1875MHz or 2000MHz) to obtain the total of 6GHz for the continuum.
ALTHOUGH OT DID NOT ALLOW ME TO MAKE THE SETUP, we will observe two QSOs, J1851+005 and J1924+156, alternately in a single track without additonal phase calibrator integrations. The fluxes of these QSOs around lamda=1mm are not known, but by extrapolating their fluxes at 7mm and 3mm, we estimate them to be around 300mJy. Each of these two QSOs is self-calibratable. The two are relatively close to each other (17 deg separation in the sky) and easy to observe in a single track.
We aim at the RMS sensitivity of 4mJy in a 0.30km/s channel. For the QSOs with flux of 300mJy, this sensitivity corresponds to the optical depth of 0.05 - 2.93 at 4 sigma. [Note, we need to detect both the decrement from the continuum, f*(1-exp(-tau)), and the absorbed flux, f*exp(-tau), significantly, where f is the flux of the QSO. To detect both at >n*sigma, the equations to be satisfied are f*(1-exp(-tau))>n*sigma and f*exp(-tau)>n*sigma.]

The goal is to simultaneosly detect 13CO and C18O J=2-1 lines in absorption across the Galactic disk at the sound speed resolution (0.3 km/s).
To cover the velocity range of the Galactic plane at the high resolution, we will use 234.375 MHz bandwidth for Baseband-1 and 2. We will configure the other bands at one of the widest bandwidths (1875MHz or 2000MHz) to obtain the total of 6GHz for the continuum.
ALTHOUGH OT DID NOT ALLOW ME TO MAKE THE SETUP, we will observe two QSOs, J1851+005 and J1924+156, alternately in a single track without additonal phase calibrator integrations. The fluxes of these QSOs around lamda=1mm are not known, but by extrapolating their fluxes at 7mm and 3mm, we estimate them to be around 300mJy. Each of these two QSOs is self-calibratable. The two are relatively close to each other (17 deg separation in the sky) and easy to observe in a single track.
We aim at the RMS sensitivity of 4mJy in a 0.30km/s channel. For the QSOs with flux of 300mJy, this sensitivity corresponds to the optical depth of 0.05 - 2.93 at 4 sigma. [Note, we need to detect both the decrement from the continuum, f*(1-exp(-tau)), and the absorbed flux, f*exp(-tau), significantly, where f is the flux of the QSO. To detect both at >n*sigma, the equations to be satisfied are f*(1-exp(-tau))>n*sigma and f*exp(-tau)>n*sigma.]

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO, 13CO, and C18O (J=1-0 and 2-1) absorption observations of the molecular ISM in the Milky Way at an unprecedented <10 milliarcsec resolution. Using compact QSOs directly behind the Galactic Plane and ALMA's high sensitivity, we can spatially isolate and spectroscopically resolve smallest molecular structures within giant molecular clouds across the MW disk, down to the thermally-bound limit of the cold molecular gas. In addition, we will determine physical parameters (i.e., column density, temperature, chemical compositions) and their variations in the typical Galactic ISM, and detect the diffuse CO gas suggested recently by extragalactic studies. We intend to obseve the two QSOs (17deg separation) alternately in a single track without phase calibrator integrations (because selfcal is possible), ALMA OT does not allow us to make the setup. Hence, the requested time in the cover is off -- we need 16h (about 2/3 of the requested time).

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Program, New York at Stony Brook, State University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
